required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Optimized Oxygen Delivery During General Anesthesia in Newborn Infants
clinical_study.official_title: Oxygen Delivery During General Anesthesia in Newborn Infants: An Open Randomized Controlled Trial of Two Levels of Inspired Oxygen.

brief_summary.textblock: An open randomized control trial investigating the delivery of two levels of inspired oxygen to newborn infants during general anesthesia.

detailed_description.textblock: Eligible infants are infants of less than 44 weeks postconceptional age and without pulmonary disease or demand for supplemental oxygen or assisted ventilation. Control subjects receive current standard of care (anesthesia induction/pre-oxygenation with 80%, maintenance of anesthesia with 40%, and recovery with 80% inspired oxygen). Intervention subjects are maintained on room air throughout the procedure and supplemental oxygen added only if necessary according to the pre-specified oxygen saturation target. Subjects are monitored according to clinical protocols AND with cerebral oximetry (NIRS), transcutaneous measurement of partial pressure of oxygen (pO2), and blood-gas analyses. Blood and urine samples are collected for later analysis of markers for oxidative stress.

primary_outcome.description: Area under curve (AUC) and absolute values of pO2

secondary_outcome.description: Reduced lung compliance as a measure of atelectasis formation
Level of isoprostanes in blood and urine

arm_group.description: High level of supplemental inspired oxygen
Supplemental oxygen only provided if oxygen saturation below target

criteria.textblock:
1. Newborn less than 44 weeks postconceptional age
2. No pulmonary disease, no oxygen requirement, or assisted ventilation
3. No genetic syndrome

overall_official.affiliation: Department of Women's and Children's Health, Uppsala University

facility.name: Uppsala University Hospital, Pediatric anesthesia Unit
